148948941.review:
HEAR YE HEAR YE, A MESSAGE TO GAMERS AND THE DEVELOPERS ALIKE

TO THE GAMERS:

As you saw before you scrolled down with the Overwhelmingly Positive reviews for this game, there is very little to be said that is negative about it.
The basis of the game is very simple. You start with a few cards and a villager. You use your villager to make other things. 
You discover cards, like structures, craftables, weapons, etc.
As the game progresses, you have invaders that enter your field, and you must defend with your villagers, that you hopefully got some weapons for.
You can buy card packs that allow you to gain more resources, and eventually grow a bigger village with more villagers. 
The simplicity of the game is very welcoming, since the speed of the game combined with the medium level of growing difficulty makes for a growing challenge that is nice and rewarding.
If you are clever, the game mechanics let you to create small "engines" that allow you to make growing your village easier and less clicking and dragging and pausing everywhere. ie putting a logging camp next to a board builder and let the cards stack and eventually make nice expensive boards.
I havnt even looked into the mods for the game yet, but I am so excited to check them out. There is so much potential to be unlocked in this game, as the groundwork enables the expansion of the game to be limitless. Very happy that it is modable.
If you are remotely interested in the game, give it a try. Its cheap, and you are supporting a great studio of honest hard working developers that have very unique game ideas.

TO THE DEVELOPERS:

Please never stop expanding this game!

Stacklands has UNLIMITED potential in terms of different mechanics and game play.
I would love to see a multiplayer co-op version, as well as a multiplayer VS mode.
I have yet to explore the mods to this game, but the developers have such a great base game to work with that they could build so many great features, themed expansions, story lines, challenges, bosses, multiplayer, weapons, enemies, mechanics, combos, etc.
I really hope that the developers, with so much positive reception to the game, have big plans for it. 
Shut up and take my money for everything for this game. 10/10

148336656.review:
I'm conflicted. 
I love the design, I love the streamlined emphasis on combining cards together and experimenting, I like exponential growth, and I love opening booster packs, with random outcomes. I... enjoy the combat.

But there's a lot of needless hassle built into the game. I haven't found any fence building, where you can seperate non-enemy cards from moving around. I haven't found any conveyor belts or beasts of burden that'll move vegetables back into the garden as soon as they harvest, or similar. 

There's an interesting early-game balance in having the right amount of villagers where you can produce the most without starving yourself by harvesting more fruit bushes than returns to you via fruit and soil/farms/gardens.

So I'm left at an impasse, where I either never pause and have inefficient moons (a.k.a. turns) or grind the game down to a halt to micromanage every single garden and stove. This dragging around every single second is made worse by moving animals, the fact that cards can be pushed around, and the inability to properly organize. 

At its largest, the playspace is also way too cramped to have nice, segmented breathing room.

Combat was also always an afterthought for me. When you go on an incursion, you'll face all types of enemies with counters and advantages. Since you don't know what you'll face, a generic equal split of classes had the most consistency, so equipping whatever strongest stuff I had was best. Counters are neat on the defensive, when you can actually pick your battles. 

I haven't beaten the game yet and don't intend to, either. I've unlocked the university and I'm making about 100 coins every moon. Whatever surprises there might be in the future, I can't be bothered dragging cards anymore. I see there's gold I might be able to smelt at some point and a musket in this game, but after building a temple just for the hell of it, I was just waiting to get a "congratulations, you win" for slowly unlocking the rest of the game.

146361934.review:
The game is extreamly fun, and you can tell everyone involved had a blast creating it as well.
When I first boulght the game, the gameplay felt shallow, a good concept that needed some polish; but after leaving it to be for a while and coming back, all of the new features and content are as welcoming as they could ever be.

The farming, the combat, the crafting, the resource gathering; all of these concepts feel conected to one another through the unconventional mean of a card game; mixing all of these factors with the board managment and your survival, keeping you on your toes the entire time.

If the stress of constantly managing your space and the board isn't your thing, the game is welcoming enough to provide various settings like pacifist mode or longer days to ensure you are having fun your way, as well as a pause button, if you ever feel like things are moving too fast. 

All in all, Stacklands is a wonderful experience, and can offer something to pretty much all types of gamers; it's easy to get into while also offering various deep systems if you ever want to invest more time into it, and the updates every once in a while also encourage you to keep coming back.

146116045.review:
It's all just cards stacking, dragging and dropping, and there isn't much else to it.

There's nothing inherently bad about completing things in order and you could wax philosophical and say "every game is a sequence of breadcrumbs," but this game is almost literally just watching progress bars fill so you can watch more progress bars fill. The concept of the game (survival game except everything is cards) is pretty neat, but man. This is basically an idle game that inconveniences you to set things up more often, and with a weak sense of scale. You're going to be micromanaging food and resources all the way until just before the end of the game with mundane mouse clicks and dragging and there won't be anything to justify the tedium. Then you'll beat it, or maybe you won't, and you probably won't think to play the game again.

Most of the excitement is in thinking about what could be coming next. Unfortunately, it never delivers on expectations. All of the explorable "locations" are also just progress bars that fill and sometimes drop mobs on you, except for specifically the Island, which itself isn't particularly unique - once you get the right set of Ideas, 1 Sand and 1 Gold Ore, you can just return to the main land and never go back again. Going to and from the Island is also a chore, since it triggers the day to end and forces you to feed all of your Villagers without accounting for the time lost. This could upset your food production if you aren't careful.

Card interactions are entirely limited to stacking, aside from combat and the Crane. Combat automatically resolves itself, with each card lining up horizontally as they fight. There isn't any way to impact the result of combat once it starts aside from changing the equipment of your Villagers as they fight, which doesn't prove to be useful very often. The Crane is a pretty underwhelming take on Factorio's Grabber. You also have to craft a card that prevents mobs from pushing around your cards - there aren't any kind of barriers you can create, there isn't any landscaping.

All in all, if you see the novel concept of "survival game with cards" and start thinking of the possibilities, chances are that this game will not deliver on them.

146038286.review:
🎮 Stacklands Review

Score: 8/10 🎮

Stacklands is a delightful surprise with its unique blend of card stacking, and real-time strategy.

🌟 The Best:

🃏 Innovative Card Stacking: Building and gathering resources through card stacking feels fresh and offers depth for mastery.
🤔 Strategic Choices: Constantly making tough decisions keeps the excitement alive. Balancing food, expansion, and defense against the clock adds thrill.
💡 Idea Card Discovery: Uncovering new card combos adds depth, making gameplay dynamic.
⏳ Real-Time Thrills: The timer adds tension, requiring constant strategizing and adaptation for survival and success.

🤔 Areas to Improve:

🍇 Random Resource Gathering: Unpredictable resource collection, like Berry Bushes, can be frustrating. More control or predictability would enhance the experience.
🚚 Travelling Cart Mechanics: Tweaks could improve the Travelling Cart's functionality.
🏁 Endgame Goals: While there's ample content, additional endgame objectives would boost long-term motivation.

In conclusion, Stacklands is a delightful surprise! Its unique mix of card stacking, village building, and real-time strategy offers an addictive and strategic indie gaming experience. Despite a few quirks, it's definitely worth a try for gamers seeking something engaging and different. 👾

145526524.review:
Oh boy, where do I start with this pixelated, card-stacking bonanza? Stacklands is what you'd get if 'SimCity' and 'Magic the Gathering' had a love child, and then that child decided to go live off the grid with some rogue-like elements. If you've ever fantasised about being the mayor of a village built entirely out of cards (who hasn't, right?), then look no further! From the moment you drop your first villager card next to a berry bush and watch those little berries get harvested, you'll know you're in for a treat. It's like playing poker, but instead of losing money, you gain resources and your villagers don't starve. #Winning 🍒

Card Packs? Oh, you betcha! It's like opening a bag of potato chips, but each chip is a possible game-changer for your little paper community. 'Oh look, a windmill card, let's slap that baby down next to the bakery!' You can practically hear your virtual villagers chanting your name as you transform their lives with every pack you open. But don't forget, the Moon waits for no one! Those little munchkins need to eat, or else you're going to have a village that looks like a 'Where's Waldo' of skeletons. 💀😂

The ultimate goal? Show that big baddie who's boss by decking out your villagers like medieval superheroes and sending them into battle. It's like 'Avengers: Endgame,' but instead of the Infinity Gauntlet, you've got a Cardopedia! Don't want to fight? That's cool; just enable 'Peaceful Mode' and make love, not war. But where's the fun in that? All in all, if you've ever wanted to play God with a deck of cards, Stacklands is your sanctuary. The only thing missing is a card that summons a therapist to help you deal with your newfound addiction to this game. 🤣🃏

145462276.review:
The premise of this game, which is stacking cards to combine them for additional effects, is very interesting. Other games have experimented with this sort of mechanic before, such as cultist simulator and even some prehistoric browser games, but this game is the first to make it feel the most "game-like" for me. I love the idea of stacking cards to get certain combinations, which then exponentially tumbles out of control in what you can do. The problem is that It feels very whimsical and new at first, but quickly becomes tedious and repetitive. 

Lets start by laying down what you can do in this game. Your overall goal of the game is to advance your tribe by developing your cards into new tools, food, and equipment. You have to manage your villagers by feeding them, equipping them, and sending them into combat. There is a basic tech system, which is essentially going from wood/stone to iron and then finally to gold. But ultimately, its pretty simple. Getting new cards is done by buying in-game card packs. These packs are bought with coins and the coins are earned by selling your cards (all cards have a coin value). You can just experiment with resources to discover new crafting recipes or you can get idea cards. Idea cards are random drops from the card packs you buy and they list exact recipes for new tech. You start with only a few card packs to buy but new card packs to purchase are discovered when you make certain progress with tech/recipes. Once you have discovered all card packs and the cards inside those packs (the game will let you know), you have found everything the game has to offer. Combat is also pretty simple. Send your units into battle and they will auto hit the enemy directly across from them. There are 3 types of damage and they form a rock-paper-scissors effectiveness triangle (magic --> range --> melee --> magic). The way to beat the game is buy defeating the final demon lord boss.

Now, I would have really enjoyed this 10-15 Civ building ride, except the game is bogged down by two major flaw's. 
One, automation. Stacking cards on top of each other in the beginning is fun. That fun evaporates when you have to keep stacking the same cards over and over. And it only gets worse as new tech come into the picture. Now, there is a tiny amount of automation and management, but no where near what you need or smooth enough. And this automation comes into picture towards the latter half of the game. I would say in the last couple hours even. It really bogs down everything you do and the joy of discovering new stuff. 

Two, card movement. At first, I really enjoyed managing where my cards were and how things were organized. But then I soon realized that cards crashing into other cards moves them. That means when an iron pops out of a mine and lands on a carrot, it moves the carrot. When an enemy spawns and starts roaming around, any cards it runs into, move. You could have an entire farm set up that auto makes carrots and is all neatly organized just how you like it. Only to come back a minute later and everything has shifted around because the carrots flying out have pushed the cards. The game is actively trying to ruin your set ups. And no, that's not a fun mechanic. This one is less severe than the automation problem because it doesn't completely ruin the experience, but it is a little infuriating. 

So because of these two flaws, I found myself towards the middle and especially towards the end, wanting the game to come to a close. I started to dread finding new buildings and resources to make because that meant more clutter that moved around, and more things I couldn't automate. The bedrock for this game is really amazing. I'm glad I did give it a go because it was a little eye opening on how creative you can get with card stacking. I could see a whole genre emerging from this and cultist simulator. But I don't think I'm ever going to touch this specific game again. 


Overall 3/5: A decently fun bite-sized Civ game that experiments with a rarely used card stacking mechanic. The mid and late game is bogged down by a severe lack of automation forcing you to stack cards repeatedly you have already stacked before. The fact that cards can be moved around by other cards also brings in unnecessary frustration. You could skip this one but its short enough that I think it has value in just experiencing how unique it is.

145443393.review:
[h1]Quick Ratings[/h1]

[b]Overall[/b]: 4/10  - Stacklands is a game about survival, decorated in a card-style gimmick. It is click intensive and doesn't really offer anything new or unique in terms of gameplay.

[b]Graphics[/b]: 6/10
[b]Gameplay[/b]: 3/10
[b]Music/Audio[/b]: 5/10
[b]Uniqueness[/b]: 4/10
[b]Monetisation[/b]: 6/10

[hr][/hr]

[h1]Detailed Info On Ratings[/h1]

[b]Graphics[/b] - The graphics are fine. I'd say slightly above average, because they are clean. Very simple.

[b]Gameplay[/b] - The gameplay is very boring and also click intensive. You need to survive each day, by having at least 1 villager alive by the end of it. This is based around so many overused modern survival game ideas (not dying of hunger for example), but it doesn't execute it in any interesting way in terms of gameplay. It's just tedious and annoying. It's not particularly difficult, and there is basically no strategy. The card theme is merely a gimmick, the core gameplay underneath it is bad.

[b]Music/Audio[/b] - It's fine. Not particularly memorable. Not bad.

[b]Uniqueness[/b] - What drew me to the game was that it looked unique. I was fooled by the card aspect. It's anything but unique. It's the same old survival tropes wheeled out again. Instead of catching a fish and cooking it, you are just dragging a berry card over a villager card. I gave some points for the card aspect, but it really is just a gimmick.

[b]Monetisation[/b] - It's ok as far as I can tell. I removed some points because it seems as though they're going down the DLC nickle and grab route. The price is also arguably overpriced at £8, for such a simple game with not much to it.

[b]Overall Thoughts[/b] - While initially looking unique, it doesn't offer anything interesting in terms of gameplay. It's not difficult at all. It's a slog to play through and I have no motivation to, there is no reward for doing so. Ok, I survive another day, so I get to click on more card packs and do more intensive clicking that lacks any required strategy. Good survival games reward the player for surviving (by unlocking a new equipment that makes your life easier and less click intensive for example). This game rewards the player for surviving by throwing more card packs to open, more complications, more text to read, and more recipes to keep track of. It's a simple game. It's a boring game. And it's vastly overrated in my opinion.

144996306.review:
This game was a welcome distraction. It was engaging enough to keep me busy for around 20 hrs. The game play is very satisfying to play to want to keep uncovering more. Unfortunately, the fact that this game basically can go on forever with no real Meat and Potatoes to speak of after you hit the "Final Final Boss" It starts to run out of steam. And then, WAM DLC, and the obsession starts all over again. And as quickly as it came it then again quickly fades. The DLC that was offered provided some serious upgrades to the game play mechanic to keep certain events from happening, or to purposely let them happen to see different things occur that may either net you additional resources, or desperately needed gear. There are some SERIOUS usability quirks with this game, but are manageable which are kinda part of it's charm. Examples being fiddly card placement annoying you, or unable to figure out what you are trying to make with what resources you currently have, you have to work your way backwards from what you are actually trying to build which can be frustrating. I wasn't expecting to enjoy this game as much as I did, but I recommend to give it a try, even if it isn't on sale. I'm happy there is modding support and there are a few good looking mods out there that may solve some of these quirks, but once you reach near "peak resources" so your not wanting of much, there is nothing to hinder, or push you to go farther and that's when the cracks really start to show themselves in the game play loop. In under 30 hours I have gotten all the achievements, for those who are achievement collectors. I think the challenge modes are a real solid addition, and potentially could be more sustainable. the addition of food spoilage does help to make sure your managing those resource carefully, A more challenge focused mode could be really helpful in getting some more life out of this game, a crossword puzzle sort of day mode. There isn't much "content" add in Stacklands for the modding community. If I knew more about programming, I'd probably give it a go and try to implement this challenge mode feature.  New Weapons and Classes might help expand the game, but you would also have to bring more challenging everyday enemies. Weather events might be a useful addition, rain could speed up crops but bring the threat of wolves or other beasts to your flat cardboard based village of sorts. Dynamic changes would help liven up challenge mode for sure. I think the Trees/Fruit Trees could really just become their own kind of permanent resource card with a certain number of them put in a stack, like 10x to make an Apple Grove for example, but takes a lot of time to make it a reality. beyond 10 villagers you start to see diminishing returns as you may have a lot of villagers out there sitting around doing nothing. 7 seems to be the sweet spot, but you can't take them all with you. More incentives for having villagers and villagers leveling up when given the aging mechanic in the DLC for upgrading in their class so to speak could be a really cool addition. There needs to be more things happening to keep your attention, but not so much to be overwhelming or an annoyance. every 3 or so days I kept finding myself asking, now what? The sudden appearance of the Final Final Boss was abrupt, and I was very lucky I had the right set of villagers and gear to sit there and decimate him. The threat of the portal spawning creatures diminished over time, so you could do what you wanted, but then took away reasons to keep playing. Potentially this could be a breakout hit, even a streaming game, if there was more incentive to keep playing like many Rogue-likes out there. More refinement of what makes this game great, more incentive to play, less annoyances, something else to do with the structure cards(sheds,cathedrals, warehouses, ect ect). Don't get me wrong, this game does feel polished to a certain extent, but I think they stopped polishing after a certain amount of time to get the game out. It needs more - Stacklands 2? , more DLC - It's in the hands of the developers now to see if they want to continue this game. 

TLDR: Thanks for the unique and interesting experience of playing Klondike / Solitaire and allowing my face cards to do battle :)  -  Final score 7/10 - Enjoyable, but a medium length experience that may not bring you back to keep playing this game.

144387042.review:
Such a weird game.  It's pretty cheap and that's a very good thing, else I would never recommend it.  In my review, I'll focus on the not so good aspects of the game.  The 96% positive reviews are nice, but is it really an instant buy kind of game?

It's a micromanagement hell or heaven, depending on what's your personal view on micromanagement.  As the game progresses and you get access to more buildings, more equipment, more villagers, it adds to the micromanagement required.

Each villager can be equipped with 3 pieces of equipment.  Ofc, they get more powerful by doing so.  But the difference between most equipment is underwhelming.  As long as you have enough villagers and you equip them with something, you'll get pretty good results.

Recipes for new stuff can be bought.  However, there's some RNG involved.  It took me forever to find the recipe for a smelter.  That stalled all progress.  I finally got it, but running in circle while waiting for it was not enjoyable.

The cards on the board keep getting kicked and moved for many reasons.  It is annoying.  There's an item that can help with that at some point, but it's not available early game and you'd need tons of it to really make a difference.

My villagers were slowly healing as time passed, no idea at what rate exactly.  However, I completed the game without ever finding another way to heal them out of combat.  It could be that it's just impossible.  Or it could be that I missed the way to do it.  Either way, it's bad.  If there is a way to heal them that I missed, it should have been more obvious than it is.

I played for 30 hours.  I had fun for about half that time, which isn't bad for the price.  The rest was a grind, micromanagement, and more of the old stuff I had already seen.

15 hours of fun.  Not too bad.  I would feel very cheap to not recommend Stacklands, because of its price.

If you want to know why this game is any good, then maybe you should read other positive reviews, there's plenty of them.

144008445.review:
The game is interesting, and worth a try, but it has some big problems. Like the crafting, exploration, and combat elements have very satisfying progression and that nice kind of slightly goofy creativity that makes this type of game fun.

[h2]Upkeep[/h2]

Put simply the game has way way too much upkeep. For upkeep tasks you have to feed your villagers, fight off attackers, keep yourself within the card limit, and organise your cards. Of these upkeep tasks combat and the card limit are fun challenges and the other two are painful chores.

First of all organising cards in this game is really frustrating. The cards bounce off each other when they get too close, which keeps things from being covered but will quickly nudge all of your nicely lined up cards out of position. There are a lot of cards that produce more cards which makes the problem so much worse. This made me want to avoid what should be some of the most fun interactions in the game: opening card packs and exploring.

The card packs are especially frustrating for a few little reasons. You buy them from the top of the board, which is awful because stacks grow downward taking up more vertical space, so the top of the board would be the best place to put many things if not for this. There is also the incredibly obnoxious interaction where when you buy one with a chest it immediately puts the chest and pack on top of each other and they shove away from each other being as disruptive as possible for nearby cards.

The food system is frustrating for a few reasons. The major one is that because the food values needed for your villagers are so small, the crafting times for a lot of the steps in making food are very long. This makes it very easy to lose villagers barely to not having enough time to finish something. The time values in the game are hidden as well so you can't easily determine if this is going to happen ahead of time.

The other big frustration with food is that care was taken to make it difficult to automate. This means that you need to spend a lot of time coming back and babysitting it, and it makes a mess of the stuff around it spewing out cards. You do have the ability to take most actions while the game is paused, but taking advantage of that for every little thing slows the pace of the game to a crawl.

[h2]Quality of Life[/h2]

It will be interesting if they keep adding to the game and improve on the above. They might also just be able to sidestep the problem by giving you enough quality of life to counterbalance the above issues.

The game has very low visibility in a few ways that would be fairly easy to improve and that would make it a lot easier to manage the chaos.

The first of which is the fact that the kind of minimal aesthetic of the game really hurts your ability to be able to quickly see what is going on. On the cards themselves the easiest things to make out are the card type, the health/food, and the value. With the exception of enemy cards being easy to spot these are some of the least important bits of information to give priority to. The card icons need to be the most obvious things on the card. An accessibility option to make the icon circle in a different colour for each individual card would help enormously with playing the game(even if it makes it much uglier). The icons of similar cards also look very similar which looks great but doesn’t help with telling them apart. This wouldn’t help much with when the cards are stacked though, the name line would have to be clearer for that or there would have to be some other indicator(like showing a task icon for what is happening above the top card).

The other visibility issues that show up are that cards with higher numbers on them could probably use other indicators to help the user quickly parse them at a glance (like chest fullness as a bar), you don’t really have any way of knowing how many cards you have and where, the unnecessary info box scroll is infuriating, it isn’t easy to see what the stats of weapons are(or how they sum up), and you need to click through to see what equipment villagers have.

[h2]Good Stuff[/h2]

This is the only game I’ve ever played where regular enemy invasions aren’t infuriating. For how often they happen they have a good amount of variety, they aren’t that disruptive, and they drop great loot. Having them just drop all sorts of random things is a great decision. You don’t have that many of any item at a time in the game and resources stay useful for a long time. This is a lot more fun than the typical dropping just equipment/money/food that many games do which gets repetitive much faster.

The game has a lot of stuff in it so you keep getting those good dopamine hits from unlocking more useful stuff pretty often(especially compared to most roguelikes). Plus gambling with the card packs is a great source of dopamine(unless you just need one thing).

Death isn’t very punishing. Losing villagers even has some upsides and you keep a lot of progress between whole runs just in terms of the unlocked knowledge. Building back up when you have that knowledge is very fast, which is quite a feat for a crafting game.

144004764.review:
All my beta-male friends that are playing Baldur's Gate 3 simply could just play this game instead. 
Here's why:
- [Immersive Storyline] The Demon Lord has been locked away and only you and your incessant need to buy card booster packs are the only way to unlock the seal and defeat the evil one. Equip your villagers and enter into automated turn-based combat, enforced by a rock-paper-scissors class advantage system and defeat small hordes of somewhat horrifying enemies such as wolves, skeletons and slimes.
- [Direct and open relationships] Unlike Baldur's Gate characters (Which I've never played at all since I'm not a lame dnd fanatic), villagers do not have any feelings or judgement whatsoever. There is no race involved. No care about gender or ethics. No one cares if you romanced the red tomboy because you got lucky on a few dice rolls and took her out on a few dates in a dungeon or something. You place two villager cards on a house card and you get a baby card. That's it. Any two villagers. So much better than having artificial feelings involved.
- [Party management] Don't worry about mulling over character sheets, each villager has their own head slot, armor slot, and a weapon slot that defines their class. That's it. If they die, they drop all their items and leave the world forever, waiting for you to hook two random villagers up to make a replacement. If you've never experienced chinese economics before, this is probably the best and subtle way to learn.

143612761.review:
If you thought this was a review about the game you thought wrong have a Beef Wellington.

STEP 1
Heat oven to 220C/fan 200C/gas 7.

STEP 2
Sit the 1kg beef fillet on a roasting tray, brush with 1 tbsp olive oil and season with pepper, then roast for 15 mins for medium-rare or 20 mins for medium. When the beef is cooked to your liking, remove from the oven to cool, then chill in the fridge for about 20 mins.

STEP 3
While the beef is cooling, chop 250g chestnut (and wild, if you like) mushrooms as finely as possible so they have the texture of coarse breadcrumbs. You can use a food processor to do this, but make sure you pulse-chop the mushrooms so they don’t become a slurry.

STEP 4
Heat 2 tbsp of the olive oil and 50g butter in a large pan and fry the mushrooms on a medium heat, with 1 large sprig fresh thyme, for about 10 mins stirring often, until you have a softened mixture.

STEP 5
Season the mushroom mixture, pour over 100ml dry white wine and cook for about 10 mins until all the wine has been absorbed. The mixture should hold its shape when stirred.

STEP 6
Remove the mushroom duxelle from the pan to cool and discard the thyme.

STEP 7
Overlap two pieces of cling film over a large chopping board. Lay 12 slices prosciutto on the cling film, slightly overlapping, in a double row.

STEP 8
Spread half the duxelles over the prosciutto, then sit the fillet on it and spread the remaining duxelles over.

STEP 9
Use the cling film’s edges to draw the prosciutto around the fillet, then roll it into a sausage shape, twisting the ends of cling film to tighten it as you go.

STEP 10
Chill the fillet while you roll out the pastry.

STEP 11
Dust your work surface with a little flour. Roll out a third of the 500g pack of puff pastry to a 18 x 30cm strip and place on a non-stick baking sheet.

STEP 12
Roll out the remainder of the 500g pack of puff pastry to about 28 x 36cm.

STEP 13
Unravel the fillet from the cling film and sit it in the centre of the smaller strip of pastry.

STEP 14
Beat the 2 egg yolks with 1 tsp water and brush the pastry’s edges, and the top and sides of the wrapped fillet.

STEP 15
Using a rolling pin, carefully lift and drape the larger piece of pastry over the fillet, pressing well into the sides.

STEP 16
Trim the joins to about a 4cm rim. Seal the rim with the edge of a fork or spoon handle.

STEP 17
Glaze all over with more egg yolk and, using the back of a knife, mark the beef Wellington with long diagonal lines taking care not to cut into the pastry.

STEP 18
Chill for at least 30 mins and up to 24 hrs. Heat oven to 200C/fan 180C/gas 6.

STEP 19
Brush the Wellington with a little more egg yolk and cook until golden and crisp – 20-25 mins for medium-rare beef, 30 mins for medium. Allow to stand for 10 mins before serving in thick slices.

I usually wait till I'm about done with a game before reviewing, but I can already tell this is worth the full 8 dollars, or especially if it's on sale.

I was initially a bit put off by the simple-looking screenshots, wondering how it could be much with such boring-seeming cards. It turns out this is almost a bit of a colony sim, where you need to manage your time and resources to prosper. While that concept isn't unique, doing it through using cards is.

143349947.review: A great showcase of a game using a very, very simple core mechanic to hang all its ideas on to reasonable effect! The near constant wrestling with displaced cards is a real aggravation at times, but the ability to automatically align cards to the grid with the E key helps considerably, and some additional organizational options unlock in-game as you play. It has a strangely adorable art style with goofy looking creatures and characters that really makes discovering new cards a treat beyond just the mechanical rewards, if you're into cute, weird, Adventure Time-esque little beasties. It's not a profoundly deep or challenging experience but it's got a polished enough UX that the game just flows in a way that's surprisingly hard to break free from. 143310968.review:
Cool rewarding game! I enjoyed ordering the mess :) About 10 hours for all achievement run, and another 6 for building a satisfying base ( posted some screenshots) with automated food production, on demand infinite resources and a cool army build for farming stable portals ( enough heal and damage for very long runs)

Some thoughts for future updates:
Wold be cool if the crane system would work better for automated production:
- For example the crane could stop or switch targets if the current target is full and cannot accept any more resources. The production could stop also if the crane detects a full crate. 
- When more cranes pick up from the same resource magnet, currently one crane is favored over the others in transferring the item, resulting in an uneven distribution of goods. It would be cool if the cranes would alternate, or could detect which slot needs more resources and deliver there. 
- The magic glue sometimes fails when a big fight starts. A bit frustrating, especially for control freaks :)) ( and these types of games are usually played by such people)

142058484.review:
An interesting combination of genres including roguelite, resource management, and village builder but it works. It's good to see Sokpop change their development philosophy from putting out a game per month and never revisiting it again, to going back to add more updates to ones that players found especially fun and interesting.

The player has two ways of progression, you can purchase card packs hoping to find a new "idea" card describing a recipe, or you can just guess at combining stuff and see if it results in anything. Unlocked "ideas" persist between games so while you might take until day 24 to figure out how to build a lumber camp on your first game, you could focus on getting one ASAP the next game. Stacklands will thus be good for at least several playthroughs if you find the gameplay loop interesting. I think it would be difficult to beat in a single try without relying heavily on external resources and looking up recipes.

Enjoying it so far and looking forward to trying to 100% it.

140530277.review:
In short, Stacklands is a fun and innovative game that is good but tends to buckle under its own weight at the end. I think it's worth the price and is a fun game - keep that in mind as I go into a bit more detail about some of the friction points down below.

As I mentioned, Stacklands tends to become a bit of a slog as time goes on. It kind of has the 'inventory hell' problem that some games have, where you're essentially a god but still have to figure out where you're going to put all these damn sticks that keep filling up you pockets. It's a bit overwhelming when you have so many cards, which themselves are producing cards. And yes, you can create chests, but I haven't figured out a convenient way to access the things inside the chests besides taking them out one at a time. And cards slide around all over the place unless you have glue, which kind of sucks to make. And yes, you can automate things using a crane, but those suck to make too, and also take up a lot of space to use. And at some point you'll be swimming in coins. You can make a wishing well to help throw them away, but the materials required to make it appear (at least for me) only once you're neck deep in coins. Maybe I'm asking too much. It seems like a lot of solutions exist, but they're pretty DIY - what I would like are some kind of global improvements (ie make this and now all cards will stick in place) or something of the like. The solutions themselves feel like a bit of a hassle, and often come when you're absolutely clamoring for them (which I get is a balance - but it feels too weighted in favor of the 'generating need' side rather than the 'fixing the issue' side). 

Again, Stackland is a great game with a lot of heart, I just think some tweaks to utilities would make more enjoyable for me personally.

Th roughly enjoyed all the management game-play this game had to offer. The combat is also nuanced and fun. However, performance on the 

STEAM DECK

is unfortunately bad.
On vanilla settings the game regularly drops to 40 FPS and if you have it on for a sufficient period, it even dips to 20FPS. Most of the time it keeps hovering between 20 & 40 FPS, with all the components running at 30% usage. 

It looks like an optimisation problem, because the components are not pitted to a 100% and performance drops proportionally to the cards increasing on screen, Performance after 200+ cards is terrible.

Specifics (in case the devs see the review),
Steam Deck 64GB,
Deck running on factory settings. Nothing changed.
Game installed on micorroSD card.

Everything gets moved around to destroy your organization whenever anything spawns or moves through it. Your cards producing other cards will throw things you've placed near them away, even occasionally when they should stack. The item you can create through a rough grind of resources to stick your cards in place disables most stacking or production, rendering it pointless.

After having done some research, I have come to the conclusion all these frustrating aspects of the game are entirely intentional. Most of the game is designed to look relaxing and neat with obvious systems in place for organization and growth. The rest of the game is programmed to disallow these features to work to the frustration of the player. There is no ultimate point to the game other than forcing the player to power through these obstacles with mechanics shown in the future to mitigate them. As described, these mechanics simply do not work and force the player into extra grinds for no benefit.

Absolutely a waste of time, and that would be fine if it was a relaxing waste of time. It is not.

138384747.review:
La verdad, no me esperaba que este juego me enganchase tanto como lo ha hecho. Para mi es uno de los mejores juegos que he jugado últimamente, sin exagerar. A ojos de cualquiera puede parecer un juego bastante sencillo, con una interfaz que al principio no acaba de convencer y te piensas que es el típico juego mal hecho y con unas mecánicas tope rebuscadas e injugables. Pero no, para mi sorpresa es todo lo contrario. Ahora explicaré punto por punto todo lo bueno y malo que tiene este juego.

Para empezar el objetivo del juego es acabar con lo que parece ser una bruja dentro la cuál amenaza a nuestro pueblo con múltiples hordas de enemigos cuando aparece el extraño portal (aunque hay algunos jefes los cuales también te supondrán un desafío acabar con ellos). Tienes que evitar a toda costa que estos monstruos acaben con tus aldeanos ya que si mueren todos, acabaría tu partida. 

El nombre del juego representa totalmente la mecánica de este, ya que vas a tener que hacer stacks, muchos stacks, para completar este juego y avanzar en él. La verdad que nunca me hubiese imaginado que un juego con este tipo de mecánica pudiese enganchar tanto. 

Organizarte en este juego es crucial, ya que vas a notar que cuando estés haciendo muchos stacks, las cartas se van a ver colisionadas entre sí provocando aún mas el desorden en tu tablero. Pero este juego la verdad es que ha pensado en todo. Para ello puedes fabricar cofres de almacenamiento, que poniéndolos debajo de una mina o fundición, los materiales se guardan automáticamente en ellos, y no solo eso, esta a tu disposición la fabricación del pegamento, el cuál hace que cualquier stack que tengas sobre él, se quede pegado en el tablero y deje de moverse, algo que es muy necesario a la hora de tener un juego limpio y organizado.

Existen dos tipos de biomas en los que vas a poder jugar, uno será el bosque y el otro la playa. Esto lo hace mas refrescante aun, ya que dentro de cada bioma podrás hacer unas cosas y en el otro otras, invitándote a descubrir nuevos crafteos y funciones dentro de cada uno.

En cuanto a las batallas con criaturas, no hay nada que destacar, el combate es muy sencillo. Tampoco se le puede pedir mucho mas a un juego de este estilo, no va a tener un combate super desarrollado. Pero sí que se tendrá en cuenta la armadura y el arma que usen tus aldeanos para poder hacer x cantidades de daños a ciertos enemigos. Algunos enemigos son mas vulnerables a la magia y otros al daño físico, por lo que te hace pensar en algún tipo de estrategia antes de combatir contra ciertos enemigos.

La verdad es que todo tiene una función y todo tiene un porqué, tiene tan bien cimentadas las bases y tan bien ejecutada las mecánicas y funciones que se van desarrollando que pocos fallos se le pueden atribuir a este título.

Pasarás inevitablemente por todos los crafteos, edificaciones, funciones posibles que ofrece el juego para pasártelo al 100%. Esta muy bien pensado el hecho de que todo, en cierta manera, esté ligado para lograr un objetivo.

Quizá algo que me parecía desesperante y ocurría de seguido, era al combatir contra un monstruo con un grupo grande de aldeanos.  Lo que ocurría era que todos los aldeanos se ponían en fila y de alguna manera lograba mover y desordenar mis stacks incluso con pegamento.

En conclusión, un juego muy divertido, adictivo y con un precio asequible, lo cual me hace preguntarte ¿Qué haces que no lo has comprado ya?

138152741.review:
It's not a bad game for sure, but not awesome either. It has equal amount of incredible and horrible parts:

[h1]Incredible: [/h1]

The gameplay is incredible: The mix of factorio with more active playstyle is fun to play. How many hours of AFK have you put into games with resources? Minecraft, factorio, cookie clicker, they all have the issue of boring stretches of waiting as your farms give you the necessary resources to continue playing the game.

This game solves it neatly. There aren't some minigames to play while you build up resources or other gimmicks to make the wait worthwhile. Instead, time itself is used as a resource because of the day mechanic, not as an arbitrary roadblock to lengthen the time used in the game: A villager building something needs few seconds, which prevents them from gathering food, generating valuables or fighting monsters. And at end of each day, you need food to sustain the villagers. So time is an resource. It's a simple solution, and it works.

[h1]Mid:[/h1]

The user experience could be better. Many reviews complain about some basic mechanic like how animals and monsters push your cards around and how it's hard to organize an automatic factory because generated cards are placed randomly around the table. There are in-game solutions to these though, like animal pens and resource magnets.

However, having the recipes and items required for these solutions unlocked randomly as the game progresses is a stupid decision.

If there's an issue with user experience, why not fix it at the source? Why do animals and monsters push cards around? Why are generated cards placed randomly? There's no good reason to do this, it doesn't change how the game is played, it just makes it more annoying before you have unlocked the solution for these issues.

[h1]Horrible:[/h1]

Even if some issues have in-game solutions, many don't. Cards stack downwards, so creating a proper storage step between two generative cards is impossible. If the cards stack too much, it's end cannot be reached by other cards and cannot be pulled from or pushed into without micromanaging the stacks. There's many of minor issues like these that cascade into larger annoyances, from how 1/8th of all board space is used by board space increasing cards to how the best automatic food farms, like a milk farm, fill 1/4th of the board with all the food it's generating, and you can't turn them off and back on easily.

There is even a secondary playfield you can unlock, which is meant to be a "hard" mode, as unused food spoils over time. But you can just use hot pots to store the foods without spoilage, which trivializes the entire mechanic.

Easy to pick up, hard to put down.  Absolutely recommended, especially for only $5!

I do have a few things to gripe about:

If you really get into the weeds on resource management (mid/endgame), you'll find some of the automation tools they added to the game are kind of half baked.  They work sometimes and other times, they are frustrating.  [spoiler]  Cranes can just start flinging cards around for no particular reason.  They can fix themselves without intervention.  Or not.  I found this happened most often when multiple cranes were pulling from the same source.  Cards get a little moved around? No problem, the crane just grabbed your lumberjack and threw him into the sawmill.  Totally fine.  -_- [/spoiler]  Anyway, once I discovered how unreliable these were, I quickly discarded plans to fully automate my food supply.  Handling some wood production, sure, but not something that could result in villagers starving if it broke.

Animals and fights knocking around your carefully arranged cards becomes a test of your patience.  Either you accept it or you don't.

I wish there was a better explanation of combat.  I eventually figured it out on my own, but for about the first half of the game, I just let my villagers fight.  I had no idea that you could rearrange your units *during combat* to achieve the most efficient match ups.  Total game changer.

Despite the above, the game is a lot of fun.

137714391.review:
This game is surprisingly fun for such a simple concept and at a small price. I would of paid a good $15 for it if I knew how fun it'd be for me personally!
Basically, it's a card game.. And a resource management game.. And a rogue like? Somehow, it's all of that and more! The card game part is more of an aesthetic until you get to combat, where it very much is, with enemy types, equipment, weapons, and headgear to choose from to change your card's battling type (Magic, Range, or Melee).
For resource management, that's almost the entirety of the game. You use your villagers to make sure you have food to feed those villagers. Then you have to make sure you don't have too many cards on your board that you have to sell them, so you build Sheds and Warehouses, which also expands the board itself. The more villagers you have, the more you can do, and you even need multiple villagers to build something like a temple (Don't do anything with the temple until you're ready to fight something with like 300 HP, which is a lot when your little guys do around 1-4 damage). 
Now for the rogue like. How is it a rogue like? You learn, that's how! You unlock ideas and card packs as you play. Ideas are like your own personal wiki, they tell you how to build things and a little bit of what those things do. You also unlock new card packs by doing quests. When all of your villagers die and you have to start over the game, it weirdly isn't as frustrating as it can be for some games. I think this is because you've gained Ideas, yes, but also general knowledge. You know what you need to do for the future. You now know the recipes, but also how to make sure you don't die or what's the most stable way of feeding your village to the point you can safely increase the population.
Obviously, I heavily suggest this game for those who like resource management specifically, since it's most of the game and the other aspects are significantly less prevalent, but pleasantly there.

137029789.review:
There aren't that many games of this genre, but Stacklands has a lot of similarity to Cultist Simulator - a card stacking, slightly idle game about uncovering gameplay and discovering recipes.  In this case, the difference is that Stacklands is also something of a colony builder, with small elements of action. It obviously doesn't match the narrative experience of Weather Factory's machines, but that's fine - this one is more about chill vibes and an enjoyable experience.  Mechanically, it is mostly the games superior, with clear objectives, good guideposts, satisfying loops, and a rising complexity of action.

Where the game generally falls down is in the later stages - the more cards you are managing, the more you want for effective tools to prevent busywork.  Manually sifting through manure so you can create individual farm plots in the dozens feels awkward, particularly when the obvious fix would be to just dump the food into the poop and let the computer sort it out.  Clean lines of automation feel vaguely possible, were it not for the abundance of intersecting cards constantly jostle and reorganize your board while you are playing on it.  The stacks dont ever condense, they simply reach absurd sizes that consume your table space and defy any hope of efficiently organizing.

Before you have reached the more interesting stages of the game you will be utterly swamped assigning something like 20-40 individual actions or recipes a minute just to try to make reasonably productive use of your time, and consulting a list of hundreds of recipes with minimal search functionality (you can search for an end product by name but can't search for products by their ingredients, which is frustrating when trying to remember what, say, magic dust goes into, or what the third tier of building type X is).  The brain burn becomes pretty real, and I wasn't inclined to find the final objectives due to the levels of annoyance in setting them up.

 That being said, for a fairly relaxed card game, this game has a flexible level of depth, an appealing aesthetic, and a pretty balanced set of systems.  It's fun to explore, lasts a good chunk of hours, and is a good mix of challenging and (usually) fair.  Just be careful, as the lack of clear objectives and the amount of additional hidden content means this game will eat a certain type of brain in that all-consuming timesink fashion that some arguably great games have.

136568910.review:
There is very little I can say about the game that other reviews or even the game's steam description haven't already said. It's a town sim, turned into a card game where you stack cards together to make things happen. You have to make sure your villagers have enough food by the end of the time, and you've got to keep your cards within the maximum board limit, which you can expand through crafting certain storage cards.

It's a game that, although early on can be bothersome to open packs and get the right cards you need, is absolutely worth the price. I originally stole it from a friend's library, but it felt like a highway robbery to not get it for myself. For the low low price of 4 USD/EUR/WhateverCurrencyYouUse™, you can get anywhere from 8-12 hours of gameplay out of this bad boy. 

It's mainly a relaxing management game before anything else, and I would definitely recommend it if you want to break the mold and have a breath of fresh air. The downside is that there isn't too much replayability unless you're planning to try your hand at speedrunning it, but that's not worth mentioning vs how enjoyable your first run will be. Cheers, and thanks for the great game @devs!

Fun game, well worth the price. It's all about engine building, essentially. Gather basic resources such as trees and stone, find a way to replenish your food stores so you can grow your population, eventually build a way to get unlimited basic resources so you can easily make the next tier of materials, and move on from there.

The early game can be a bit reliant on RNG. Maybe a tree just never comes out of a card pack leaving you without wood when you desperately need it, which can block you from progressing. Mid-game was the most interesting as you start discovering more and more recipes. The late game admittedly gets overwhelming with how many cards you are constantly managing and moving your villagers, when one would have expected a lot of those things would have been automated by then.

It was a lot of fun to move cards around, experiment, and discover different things in the game for quite a while and it's overall just a great $5 game.

135756937.review:
Played after the Order & Structure update, and before the DLC.
————————————————————————————————
I have personally enjoyed the game, but it needs to be said:
this game should have been called "Janklands" as it is 50% trying to achieve your objectives, and 50% dealing with the jank of the card placing mechanic. Despite some attempts to mitigate this in the Order & Structure update, it is an unavoidable end result of the questionable decision to go with physically interactive cards . The promotional trailers and screenshot always show you a board with few cards, because the later boards are always a mess of cards pushing each other, or glitching around the edges of the board. You can embark on the mission of using the newly added logistic cards to mitigate this, but those are janky as well, so you will spend about the same time establishing your genius board as you would by constantly fixing it instead. I have to question the decision of the developers to stick to the whole "physically interacting cards" gimmick, especially that there seems to be no upside to it.

The game currently does not feature any replayability — it is a simple exercise of completing all the quests, and, if you want, getting all the cards. This is fine, I got 20 hours out of it, but the game uses "run" terminology — as in, calling starting a new game "new run" — implying that it was desired. So I am mentioning this.

Other than that, stacking cards to turn them into other cards, that will allow you to get different cards, which will get you booster packs with even more new cards is very rewarding, and therefore addictive. I certainly have played way too late into the night on multiple occasions.

135195309.review:
While I'm not even four hours into the game, I feel like I have seen most of the content and definitely enough to review and recommend. This game takes the actual actions of punching trees for wood, mining rocks, and all the usual early-survival game action and turns it into a card game. Stack certain card combos and you can upgrade, receive new items, and create new buildings. Like many survival games, it is all about balance; you have to make sure you have enough villagers to ensure you can fight off mobs, but you also have to make sure you have enough food production to feed those villagers. I have only made it to about 40-50 moons or so, and really look forward to seeing if I can progress into a really long run!

This will never be my favorite game ever, but I see myself coming back to this a lot when I am in-between games. It is easy to pick off where I left off and easy to go for a while without playing and just jump right back in because while there is a learning curve to "git gud," the basics are very simple.

I only lucked upon this while searching through the current sale, but would gladly have forked over the five bucks that is the normal price. I'd be shocked if I didn't end up with 20 plus hours for something I played under four dollars for.

135097967.review:
If you're tired of the same old city-building simulators, "Stacklands" might be just what you need. The game takes a unique approach by using card-based gameplay, where you acquire cards to sell drops and buy more cards. There's even a second world where you can build a small settlement, adding another layer of gameplay.

One of the standout features of "Stacklands" is the inclusion of an annoying yet humorous element: a card stack that slowly move across the screen. With drops you add more and more cards until it becomes overwhelming full on my screen. While this can be frustrating in the endgame, it adds an extra level of challenge and humor to the game.

The graphics and UI of "Stacklands" are simple, but they suit the gameplay well. The game is refreshing and provides a welcome change of pace from other city-building simulators.

Overall, I would highly recommend "Stacklands" to anyone looking for a unique and engaging take on city-building games. Just be prepared for the ticker tape of cards!

135077349.review:
Really cute presentation of card-based builder game. However, it quickly became monotonous, overwhelming, and frustrating. Managing the physical layout of your tableau is more tedious than fun. The list of recipes quickly becomes too long to keep track of, and the UI doesn't help.

Every few minutes, the grim reaper swings his scythe, and if you mismanaged your food, villagers die; if you mismanaged your stockpiles and sheds, you're forced to sell off cards.

The random booster packs are a frustrating way to acquire needed resources and discover new content. It's frustrating to open a potato and literally have no use for it, or any idea of when you'll discover a use for it.

135060504.review:
I put off buying Stacklands for quite a while, because some of the reviews said it was really short. It's not. It's roughly a 20-30 hour game, and it's ridiculously cheap.

You do almost everything in the game by making stacks of cards. The simplest is to drag a villager on top of a berry bush to harvest berries. Make a garden by dragging some cards on top of a Soil card, farm vegetables by dragging them on top of the Garden.

The main loops are setting up reliable food production, making more villagers, making money, gathering and refining resources, and making tools, weapons, and armor for your villagers. 

It plays in real time, but you can pause at any time and re-arrange things. I did a *lot* of pausing, myself.

Now and then there's combat. You sell cards periodically to buy "booster packs" of unknown cards, and the more advanced packs sometimes include monsters you must fight instead of new resources. You pile  your fighters on to the monster, and they exchange blows until they die or the monster's defeated.

"Research" in the game is "idea" cards, which tell you about a card combination, and permanently record the details in your research log. You can figure some things out on your own easily, like smelter + ore + wood -> metal bars, but the combinations for most advanced buildings aren't obvious.

This game seems purposely designed to frustrate players who like things neat and organized. When cards pop out from a building, if they land near another card, they'll push that card away. You can make neat rows of cards for a production line, but you're guaranteed that after a few cycles of production it'll be a mess because of cards pushing each other.

There are cards that make your playing area bigger. There doesn't seem to be an upper limit to your village space, but it's still going to be a colossal mess by the late game.

Other than that, it doesn't have a lot of downsides. If you're a fan of resource management / village games, it's great.

This is a great survival game made into a relaxing game of cards. Though this game may not be technologically advanced, the visuals have a nice hand-drawn visual art style that will pull you right in. Time to stack on this review.

Artstyle:
As already stated this game has a hand-drawn visual art style. The cards may not have lots of detail, but you know exactly what they are and what they do. This game is simple but in a relaxing homemade fashion. 

Atmosphere:
The calm music and visuals will help soothe you even when all your villagers are dying and fighting evil pirates. This game delivers a great stacking card game that keeps on going. Nothing more needed to mention on the atmosphere that you can't already observe in the trailer. 

Gameplay:
Don't be deceived by the title and screenshots, this game is not necessarily a deck builder but rather a survival game made out of cards. It's actually a really nice pairing but there is no "hand" in this game. It is a game where you perform actions by stacking cards on one another rather than controlling a character to an object to perform the action. 

Price:
A great game for the price and even better on sale!

Conclusion:
Look I really enjoyed the game. It's just one of the few survivor games that I would consider relaxing. The game has its own charm and golly is this game addicting.  

Score:
8/10 Berries

134987075.review:
Stacklands is a game about stacking cards. It is not a card game yet has everything to do with cards. Everything is a card and all of them can be stacked as a means of progression.

See a rock? That’s a card. See a villager? Card again. Stack them. Get some stone out of it. That stone? Yup, another card. Stack three stone and you got a block, which is a card. You get the idea. The basic formula is a tried and true one; villagers are workers and get fed once a day or die, resources get worked, farmed and improved, research is done and the game progresses. Oh no, what’s this? An evil witch has sent monsters to kill you? Kill them back, find out where they are coming from and prepare for a boss battle.

The formula works well and Stacklands doesn’t push any new boundaries there but manages to strike the perfect balance between survival, combat and growth. This makes the game easy to get into while packaging it in a card format makes it unique and interesting enough to keep one engaged.

Combat is simple and consists of turn based auto attacking by every card in the bout. No user input required. The meat of the game is resource management and growth anyway so keeping the focus away from micro managing combat is a good way to achieve that. Most of the time will be spent on making sure your villagers have enough to eat by the end of the day and securing enough resources to make the next big thig that will progress you further. Combat comes when progress is halted due to missing key components which can only be obtained through combat. Either you choose to fight or the fight comes to you eventually. Resource progression and advancement doesn’t get too deep which keeps the game short and sweet while the mystery of what’s to come keeps you plugged in and stacking cards.

Sokpop Collective have outdone themselves with this game. Their philosophy of making short games and pumping them out one by one with technical quality and a loving hand proves once again; while these games may not be as deep and lengthy as one hopes, especially when they are at the level of quality as Stacklands, it is reassuring to know we get to try more unique experiences than the collective 20 year output of a triple A studio.

Stacklands is great: fun, easy to pick up, unique and full of references. 10-15 hours to 100% for 4€, dare I even ask?

133392114.review:
[h1]Tier BC[/h1]

Stacklands is a card management survival game, or a deck version of factory games, and it finds a sweet spot for a challenging yet casual survival experience. Combat, starvation, and villager deaths brought an appropriate amount of intensity to decisions; however, with enough strategy and forethought, the player isn’t doomed to failure by chance alone, as is often the case in other games like it. Stacklands features a pleasing array of resources and crafting combinations, and I had a constant feeling of progression while playing it as the new unlocks were well-paced and kept me engaged. 

[spoiler]The secondary locations, the Desert Island and Dark Forest, brought some interesting new challenges. Their mechanical difference in allowing a subset of villagers there, yet if they died you resume control over the others, allowing a more relaxed sense of ‘adventuring’ since you don’t have to risk it all for exploration and have a monster wipe your whole village.[/spoiler]

The game showed a few sore spots for improvement, however. Some RNG in deck pulls was abysmal, with clearly no forgiveness mechanics built in / guaranteed pull rate. This was irritating when I was trying to pull for inexpensive resources (sand, flint, soil) and it took dozens of attempts to pull one, as if the game knew what I wanted and refused. Additionally, I’m not sure why anchoring/auto-sorting card stacks had to require their own expensive recipes to aid in UX -- that felt like something that should have been configurable, and not having it felt odd and mildly inconvenient. 

All in all, Stacklands is a bargain for its price. While I don’t think Stacklands brings anything particularly innovative to the genre and it lacks replayability once you beat it, it’s a fun time and I definitely enjoyed myself. At a mere $5, this game well surpassed my expectations.

This game is freaking awesome. I think it's a prime example of how a solid gameplay loop can really do wonders. I got it for $2.99 on sale, but it's more than worth the $5 they're asking for.

It's a card based village builder sim. You craft things, feed your villagers, and fend off monsters. As you sell things you can buy more card packs, that come with more resources and "ideas" for how to build new things and further your society. It's rogue-like in nature - you can get wiped by a monster invasion or not have enough food to feed your peeps, and then you start over haha.

Sticking with it and learning to adapt are important - you learn faster that way. I wiped a couple times before I really got in the groove and made it to end game. It felt good to be rewarded for innovation and sticking with the upfront difficulty.

Visuals are a simple and fun hand drawn feel. Nothing crazy, but it gets the job done.

And that's basically it haha. I don't want to say too much because I want people to experience it for themselves, it really was a blast. Highly recommend.

Very nice concept and good execution. The game has a cheery, colorful atmosphere, well-served by simple graphics and a relaxing music. The feeling of playing a card game is here, complete with clever combinations, cards stacking, and sometimes frustrating luck when opening new boosters. While the content seems to be quite large, the initial gameplay loop, while satisfying and original, gets repetitive quite fast. The polish is a bit lacking in some areas, and after a dozen turns or so it can get tedious to manage all the cards within the time of a turn. The game is also actually quite rich in content, which is great and motivating to play further, but this depth takes also the form of a large amount of resources to manage, which again quickly gets strenuous.
I can however, completely see myself coming back to this game from time to time, and having a great hour building my little card village and being crushed by goblin archers. I don't think I will ever try to 100% the game and its quests, since after 20 turns or so the game requires some very involved micro-management. But, for the price point, having an original game with a cool atmosphere and a couple hours of fun seems like a fair trade.

132448659.review:
I absolutely love this game! The concept isn't too far from your traditional game like Civilization except it's far simply and cards replace your units, resources, and structures. 

It also has a likeness to a game like Minecraft where you have to collect resources and learn about the various crafting recipes. Learning about recipes is actually a huge aspect of the game and is called, "Insight". You can earn money and sell cards you don't need then use the money to buy card packs which have a chance of include Insight cards: cards that have new crafting recipes. You can also feel free to experiment of resource combinations to try and guess the crafting recipes on your own.

I thought this game would have a high learning, but it is designed very well. From the get-go you are introduced with quests that guide you in learning how the game works. If you lose in the first few runs, it's no biggy because you pick up the quests and insight where you left off. It's up to you to bring back all the resources you had before.

I would guess that I am about 70% way through the game by now. At this point I only have two major complaints: as you get further into the game, you will start to have [i]lots[/i] of cards in your hand. This produces two problems: 

(1) A good chunk of your time will be devoted to constructing "sheds" which increase the amount of cards you can have in your hand by 4. This number is a pretty big deal in the early game, but by late game it is small and insignificant compared to the amount of cards you will be needing. Thus a considerable amount of time will be spent constructing sheds. A fix would be to introduce an upgraded version of the shed that can be constructed with late-game materials.

(2) You can stack cards, but stacks can't overlap. When you make something, the new card is spat out in it's own stack. This new stack can sometime overlap with existing stacks and cause things to shuffle around. This becomes very annoying when you have many strategically placed stacks; bogging down your efficiency. It would be nice if there were an "anchor" card that would prevent this.

[h3]Steam Deck Notes:[/h3]

Runs great. The default controls are nearly perfect. I would recommend rebinding R1 to hide the quests menu since that functionality is not bound by default.

There are only two problems I have come across: 

(1) Normally to pause the game, you press "B". Then "Y" is used to accelerate the game time. Now when you open the quest menu, the game pauses on its own and resumes when you close the menu. But if you manually pause the game before opening the menu then close it, the game will remain paused. [b]However[/b], to resume the game you will have to press "Y". For some reason, "B" stops working when you do this.

(2) There are certain in-game events that cause a small notification menu that pops up in the middle of the screen. For some reason, there is no way to close the menu (that I know of) using the controller. So you will have to use "Steam+<modifier>" to manually close the menu.

Stacklands is a really fun game where you have to manage resources and cards.

131710963.review:
I think implementing a pause button was a massive mistake.

At its core, this game has a really fun gimmick to it where you stack cards and try to stay organized lest your villagers run out of food and starve to death. This would be a great gameplay loop if SO MUCH OF THE GAME wasn't built around being able to pause and move things around as you please. Pausing and micromanaging is by far the dominant strategy but makes everything VERY tedious. If the devs leaned into the roguelite elements a little more and balanced around shorter, more chaotic runs that can't be paused, I would have much more fun with this game. You can't be a crazy card stacker and a slow, methodical management game at the same time.

131490541.review:
I can't tell if I'm way off my genre or if Stacklands really is as messy as it looks. It reminds me of Don't Starve, but you play entirely by dragging cards on top of other cards. Gathering tons of food isn't hard, combat isn't hard... but unlocking new recipes, THAT'S hard, because they're generally unlocked by buying card packs, which randomly may contain a recipe. I'm four hours in with a dozen recipes that all need Rope or Gold, but I have no idea how to make either of those!

It's definitely in the "time-waster" genre, but it really does feel like a waste of time. Nothing feels challenging and the goals are very unclear. "Make a Temple," how? "Find the Dark Forest," how? "Break a bottle," what makes you think I have bottles to break? And what's the POINT of any of these? What am I working toward? "Gather 50 food," why?? That's WAY more than my 6 villagers need!

At best, Stacklands is a representation of a novel approach to gameplay, but it feels like a concept more than a game. The aimless, random nature of the goals, reminds me of the monotony of real life. I play games to ESCAPE from that, not to simulate it in my downtime.

131435409.review:
Una sorpresa mas que agradable.

Stacklands es un juego de supervivencia roguelike de cartas , aunque no le he visto realmente el punto de juego de supervivencia , una vez aprendemos a jugar , el hecho de sobrevivir deja de ser un reto mas pronto que tarde. Nuestro objetivo en un principio es crear una pequeña civilización de aldeanos los cuales tendrán que comer a diario para sobrevivir , es decir , nos obligan a tener comida suficiente cada día si queremos continuar. En Stacklands tenemos algunos materiales básicos como la madera o la piedra , pero mas adelante iremos descubriendo nuevos sobres y nuevos crafteos para hacer crecer esta civilización y así hacer frente a los enemigos que nos encontraremos a medida que pasan las lunas. 

Con un estilo visual tan simple y minimalista , y esta base jugable tan adictiva y divertida , Stacklands se convierte de lleno en uno de los mejores indies de 2022. Por un precio mas que asequible , recomiendo encarecidamente como mínimo darle una oportunidad.
